document.docAuthor: Li, Jiayuan & Ni, Gang & Liu, Yanfei & Wang, Renzhong & Yu, Dequan
document.docTitle: Long-chain fatty acid acylated derivatives of isoflavone glycosides from the rhizomes of Iris domestica

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Long-chain fatty acid acylated derivatives of isoflavone glycosides from the rhizomes of Iris domestica

paragraph.docTitle:
Long-chain fatty acid acylated derivatives of isoflavone glycosides from the rhizomes of
Iris domestica

paragraph.docAuthor: Jiayuan Li, Gang Ni, Yanfei Liu, Renzhong Wang, Dequan Yu

paragraph.emphasis: State Key Laboratory of Bioactive Substance and Function of Natural Medicines, Institute of Materia Medica, Chinese Academy of Medical Sciences, Peking Union Medical College, Beijing, 100050, People’ s Republic of China

subSection.paragraph: Long-chain fatty acid derivatives Cytotoxicity
Antioxidation
ABSTRACT

Six undescribed long-chain fatty acid esters of isoflavone glycosides were obtained from the rhizomes of
Iris domestica
(L.). Their structures were elucidated by comprehensive spectroscopic data, alkaline hydrolysis, and acid hydrolysis. This is the first report of the long-chain (C 14 –C 18 ) fatty acid derivatives of isoflavone glycosides from natural products. Belamcandnoate B and D exhibited moderate cytotoxic activities against HCT-116, HepG2, and BGC823 cell lines with IC 50 values of 1.69–6.86 μ M. Belamcandnoate B and E exhibited 72.27 and 58.98% inhibitory activities, respectively, against Fe 2+ /cysteine-induced liver microsomal lipid peroxidation at a concentration of 10 μ M.

To date, chemical, enzymatic and chemoenzymatic acylation of flavonoids and dihydrochalcone with various acyl donors (C2–C18 chain length) has been reported ( Ziaullah and Rupasinghe, 2013 , 2016; Xin et al., 2019 ; Ziaullah et al., 2013). However, there are no reports about long-chain (C 14 –C 18 ) fatty acid esters of isoflavone glycosides isolated from natural products. The rich isoflavones in
I. domestica
enable us to obtain the chain length of fatty acid derivatives of isoflavone glycosides from this plant. In the course of our ongoing search for structurally unique and biologically diverse metabolites, six undescribed long-chain fatty acid acylated derivatives of isoflavone glycosides ( Fig. 1 ) were isolated from the rhizomes of
I. domestica .
Acylation occurs at C-6 of glucoside, and the chain length of fatty acids as acyl donors is from C14 to C18. In addition, in an in vitro bioassay, the cytotoxic, antioxidative, and anti-inflammatory activities of the isolated compounds are evaluated. Here, we describe the isolation, structural elucidation, and bioactive evaluation of compounds 1–6 .

Belamcandnoate A ( 1 ) was obtained as a pale yellow oil (MeOH). Its molecular formula, C 37 H 50 O 13 , was determined by the HRESIMS ion at [M + H] + m/z 703.33234 (calcd 703.33242), which indicated 13 indices of hydrogen deficiency. 1 H NMR data ( Table 1 ) also exhibited five hydroxyl groups at δ H 12.92 (1H, s, OH-5), 9.09 (1H, s, OH-3 ′ ), 5.57 (1H, d, J = 5.8 Hz, OH-2 ′′ ), 5.38 (1H, d, J = 6.4 Hz, OH-4 ′′ ), 5.31 (1H, m, OH-3 ′′ ), including two hydroxyl groups at the aromatic ring. A characteristic singlet at δ H 8.45 (1H, s, H-2) implies that 1 is an isoflavone. The aromatic signals at δ H 7.04 (1H, d, J = 2.3 Hz, H-2 ′ ) and 6.96 (2H, m, H-6 ′ , 5 ′ ) show the presence of an ABX aromatic system. An aromatic proton singlet at δ H 6.85 (1H, s, H-8) is observed, which suggest the presence of a trisubstituted aromatic ring A. Two methoxyl groups at δ H 3.79 (3H, s, OMe-4 ′ ) and 3.75 (3H, s, OMe-6) are assigned. The anomeric proton signal at 5.16 (1H, d, J = 8.8 Hz, H-1 ′′ ), an isolated methylene at δ H 4.29 (1H, dd, J = 14.5, 1.9 Hz, H-6 ′′ a), 4.09 (1H, dd, J = 14.5, 9.5 Hz, H-6 ′′ b), and four methines at δ H 3.75 (1H, m, H-5 ′′ ), 3.36 (1H, m, H-2 ′′ ), 3.31 (1H, m, H-3 ′′ ), 3.18 (1H, m, H-4 ′′ ) demonstrate the presence of a β -glucopyranosyl unit. These signals at δ H 0.84 (3H, t, J = 8.5 Hz, H-16 ′′′ ), 2.26 (2H, m, H-2 ′′′ ), and partially overlapping aliphatic protons at δ H 1.24–1.07 are characteristic of fatty acids. Based on the HSQC spectrum, the 13 C NMR data identified 37 resonances, which were categorized as a ketone carbonyl at δ C 180.7 (C-3); an ester carbonyl at δ C 172.8 (C-1 ′′′ ); seven oxygenated aromatic carbons at δ C 156.4 (C-7), 154.9 (C- 2), 153.0 (C-5), 152.4 (C-9), 146.2 (C-3 ′ ), 147.8 (C-4 ′ ), 132.5 (C-6); seven aromatic carbons at δ C 122.0 (C-3), 123.1 (C-1 ′ ), 119.7 (C-6 ′ ), 116.3 (C-2 ′ ), 111.9 (C-5 ′ ), 106.6 (C-10), 94.0 (C-8); a glucosyl group at δ C 99.7 (C-1 ′′ ), 76.4 (C-3 ′′ ), 73.8 (C-5 ′′ ), 73.0 (C-2 ′′ ), 70.1 (C-4 ′′ ), 63.4 (C- 6 ′′ ); as well as some partially overlapping aliphatic carbons at δ C 22.1–33.5. A detailed comparison of the spectroscopic data of 1 with those of the known isoflavone iristectorin A ( Monthakantirat et al., 2005 ) indicates that compound 1 is a long-chain fatty acid acylated derivative of iristectorin A. The HMBC correlations ( Fig. 2 ) from OMe ( δ H 3.79) to C-4 ′ and from OMe ( δ H 3.75) to C-6, along with the NOESY correlations from OMe ( δ H 3.79) to H-5 ′ and from OMe ( δ H 3.75) to H-1 ′′ indicate that two methoxyl groups are located at C-4 ′ and C-6, respectively, which further confirms the presence of iristectorin A. The HMBC correlation from H-6 ′′ to C-1 ′′′ indicates that the acylated site is located on OH-6’’. Analysis of the unsaturation of 1 reveals that the long-chain fatty acid is saturated.

footnote.paragraph: * Corresponding author. E-mail address: dqyu@imm.ac.cn (D. Yu).

subSection.paragraph: To determine the length of the fatty acid, alkaline hydrolysis by NaOH was used. Analysis of the alkaline hydrolysis products by LC–MS, reveals the molecular formulas of C 23 H 24 O 12 (MW: 492) and C 14 H 28 O 2 (MW: 228), which indicates the presence of myristic acid. Subsequently, the products of alkaline hydrolysis for 1 were isolated to yield the pure compound iristectorin A with a molecular weight of 492. For compound 1 , the characteristic signal of an anomeric proton with the coupling constant J ′′ H-1 -2’’ = 8.8 Hz demonstrates that the relative configuration of pyranohexose is β ( Usui et al., 2017 ; Bock and Pedersen, 1983 ). The absolute configuration of glucopyranosyl is defined by the GC analysis of products from the acid hydrolysis and derivatization reactions by L-cysteine methyl ester hydrochloride and trimethylsilylimidazole of iristectorin A. The acid hydrolysis result indicates that glucopyranosyl is D-glc. Therefore, 1 originated from iristectorin A esterified by myristic acid. Compound 1 was named Belamcandnoate A.

Compound 2 was obtained as a pale yellow oil (MeOH). Its molecular formula, C 38 H 52 O 14 , was deduced from the HRESIMS ion at [M + H] + m/z 733.34265 (calcd 733.34298), which indicated 13 indices of hydrogen deficiency. Compared with the corresponding NMR signals of 1 , there are spectroscopic differences due to AB aromatic system signals at δ H 6.72 (1H, d, J = 2.3 Hz, H-6 ′ ), 6.66 (1H, d, J = 2.3 Hz, H-2 ′ ), δ C 104.4 (C-2 ′ ), 110.4 (C-6 ′ ) and a methoxyl group at δ H 3.78 (3H, s), δ C 55.9 (-OCH 3 ). The methoxyl group is ascribed to C-5 ′ based on the HMBC correlations from δ H 3.78 to C-5 ′ and C-2’. The above mentioned data demonstrate that the isoflavone glycoside is iridin ( Monthakantirat et al., 2005 ). The sugar of 2 is defined as glucopranosyl by comparing the NMR data with those of glycosides in the literature ( Usui et al., 2017 ; Bock and Pedersen, 1983 ). 1 H NMR data of 2 display an anomeric proton signal at δ H 5.16 (1H, d, J = 8.6 Hz, H-1 ′′ ), which reveals the β -configuration of glucose ( J ′′ 1 -2’’ > 7 Hz) ( Bock and Pedersen, 1983 ). Using the GC analysis of acid hydrolysis products of iridin, the absolute configuration of the sugar unit is determined to be the D-configuration. Analysis of the alkaline hydrolysis products for 2 by LC–MS, reveals the same molecular weights of mw = 522 (C 24 H 26 O 13 ) and mw = 228 (C 14 H 28 O 2 ) as 1 , which indicates that iridin is esterified by myristic acid. Thus, compound 2 was named Belamcandnoate B.

Compound 3 was isolated as a pale oil. HRESIMS indicates a proton adduct ion [M + H] + at m/z 723.33417 (calcd 723.33510), which corresponds to a molecular formula of C 38 H 52 O 12 with 13 indices of hydrogen deficiency. Examination of the NMR data of compounds 3 and 1 indicates that the differences between the two compounds can be attributed to an A’ A’ B’ B’ aromatic system with signals at δ H 7.38 (2H, d, J = 10.3 Hz, H-2 ′ , 6 ′ ), 6.82 (2H, m, H-3 ′ , 5 ′ ); δ C 130.1 (C-2 ′ , 6 ′ ), 115.1 (C- 3 ′ , 5 ′ ) for 3 . Subsequently, an alkaline hydrolysis reaction was conducted, and the results of LC MS analysis show molecular weights of mw = 462 (C 22 H 22 O 11 ) and mw = 256 (C 16 H 32 O 2 ), which support that compound 3 is the palmitic acid acylated derivative of tectoridin ( Monthakantirat et al., 2005 ). Comparison of the NMR data with those of glycosides in the literature ( Usui et al., 2017 ; Bock and Pedersen, 1983 ), and the coupling constant values J ′′ 1 -2’’ = 8.9 Hz ( > 7 Hz) demonstrate that the sugar of 3 was glucopranosyl, and the relative configuration was assigned as β . An acid hydrolysis experiment shows that glucopyranosyl was D-glc. Therefore, compound 3 was named Belamcandnoate C.

caption.paragraph: 1 H (600 MHz) and 13 C (150 MHz) NMR data of compounds 1–3 (DMSO‑ d ).

subSection.paragraph: Compound 4 was obtained as a pale yellow oil (MeOH). Its molecular formula, C 42 H 56 O 14 , was determined by the HRESIMS ion at [M + H] + m/z 785.37329 (calcd for 785.37428), which indicates 15 indices of hydrogen deficiency, two degrees of unsaturation higher than 1 . The NMR data ( Table 2 ) closely resembled those of 1 . The differences mainly involved two double bonds at δ H 5.28 (4H, m, H-6 ′′′ , 7 ′′′ , 9 ′′′ , 10 ′′′ ); δ C 129.7 (C-6 ′′′ ), 129.6 (C-10 ′′′ ), 127.7 (C-7 ′′′ ), 129.6 (C-9 ′′′ ), which corresponded to the degrees of unsaturation. Analysis of the alkaline hydrolysis products of 4 by LC—MS reveals molecular weights of mw = 522 (C 24 H 26 O 13 ) and mw = 280 (C 18 H 32 O 2 ), which indicates that compound 4 was an octadecadienoic acid acylated derivative of tectoridin. The 1 H– 1 H COSY correlations show two fragments: C(2 ′′′ )H 2 –C(3 ′′′ )H 2 –C(4 ′′′ ) H 2 –C(5 ′′′ )H 2 –C(6 ′′′ )H and C(7 ′′′ )H–C(8 ′′′ )H 2 –C(9 ′′′ )H–C(10 ′′′ )H. HMBC correlations from H-6 ′′′ to C-4 ′′′ , C-7 ′′′ , C-8 ′′′ , from H-10 ′′′ to C-8 ′′′ , C-9 ′′′ , C-12 ′′′ , demonstrate that the long-chain fatty acid was 6 ′′′ , 9 ′′′ -octadecadienoic acid. Moreover, the obvious upfield shift of the bisallylic methylene signal at δ C 25.2 (C-8 ′′′ ), along with the typical carbon resonances of two allylic methylenes at δ C 26.6 (C-5 ′′′ ) and δ C 26.6 (C-11 ′′′ ) indicate that the methylene interrupted double bonds were Z -configuration ( Gunstone et al., 1977 ; Song et al., 2021 ). Therefore, the long-chain fatty acid side chain was defined as 6? Z , 9? Z -octadecadienoic acid. Besides, the NMR data were highly similar to those of glycosides in literature ( Usui et al., 2017 ; Bock and Pedersen, 1983 ), combined with the coupling constant value J = 8.8 Hz of anomeric proton, they enabled the identification of the sugar unit as β -glucose. The acid hydrolysis indicates that glucopyranosyl was D-glc. Compound 4 was defined as Belamcandnoate D.

Compound 5 was obtained as a pale oil, and the HRESIMS data displayed an [M – H] – ion at m/z 753.34924 (calcd 753.34916), which established a molecular formula of C 41 H 54 O 13 with 15 degrees of unsaturation. Considering the HRESIMS data, the molecular weight of 5 was 30 mass units less than that of 4 , which indicates the absence of a methoxy group in 5 . The comparison of the NMR data of compounds 5 and 4 reveals a difference due to different substituent groups of ring B. In the 1 H NMR spectrum, the resonances at δ H 7.05 (1H, d, J = 2.3 Hz, H- 2 ′ ), 6.95 (2H, m, H-6 ′ , 5 ′ ) are attributed to an ABX aromatic system for ring B. Comparison of the NMR data with 1 indicates that 5 and 1 share identical isoflavone glycosides. An LC MS analysis of the alkaline hydrolysis products of 5 reveals molecular weights of 492 (C 23 H 24 O 12 ) and 280 (C 18 H 32 O 2 ), which indicates that compound 5 was an octadecadienoic acid acylated derivative of iristectorin A. Similar double bonds NMR data as
4 in
side chain are displayed at δ H 5.28 (4H, m, H-6 ′′′ , 7 ′′′ , 9 ′′′ , 10 ′′′ ), δ C 129.7 (C-6 ′′′ ), 129.6 (C-10 ′′′ ), 127.8 (C-7 ′′′ ), 127.8 (C-9 ′′′ ), which supports the conclusion that 5 and 4 share the same fatty acid side chain—6 ′′′ , 9 ′′′ -octadecadienoic acid. Besides, the characteristic 13 C NMR data of two bisallylic methylenes at δ C 26.6 (C-5 ′′′ ) and δ C 26.6 (C-11 ′′′ ), and the upfield shift value of an interrupted methylene signal at δ C 25.2 (C-8 ′′′ ) are observed, which demonstrate that the geometry of double bonds Δ 6′′′, 7′′′ and Δ 9′′′, 10′′′ is Z -configuration ( Gunstone et al., 1977 ; Song et al., 2021 ). The relative configuration of the sugar unit is determined as the β -configuration according to the coupling constant value J ′′ 1 -2’’ = 8.6 Hz ( J ′′ 1 -2’’ > 7 Hz) ( Usui et al., 2017 ; Bock and Pedersen, 1983 ). The absolute configuration of D-glc is further confirmed by acid hydrolysis using GC analysis. Compound 5 was elucidated as Belamcandnoate E.

Compound 6 was obtained as a pale oil, and its molecular formula C 40 H 52 O 12 was determined by HRESIMS with [M + Na] + ion at m/z 747.33429 (calcd 747.33510), which indicated that it was 15 indices of hydrogen deficiency. Analysis of the 1 H and 13 C NMR data of compounds 6 and 4 (except the fatty acid side chains), ascribed the differences to an A’ A’ B’ B’ aromatic system at δ H 7.38 (2H, d, J = 10.3 Hz, H-2 ′ , 6 ′ ), 6.84 (2H, d, J = 10.3 Hz, H-3 ′ , 5 ′ ); δ C 130.1 (C-2 ′ , 6 ′ ), 115.1 (C-3 ′ , 5 ′ ) for 6 . To determine the length of the fatty acid chain, alkaline hydrolysis by NaOH was performed. The LC MS analysis results displayed molecular weights of 462 (C 22 H 22 O 11 ) and 280 (C 18 H 32 O 2 ), indicating that it was the octadecadienoic acid acylated derivative of tectoridin. The NMR data of 6 reveal two double bonds at δ H 5.29 (4H, m, H-6 ′′′ , 7 ′′′ , 9 ′′′ , 10 ′′′ ), and δ C 129.7 (C-6 ′′′ ), 129.6 (C-10 ′′′ ), 127.8 (C-7 ′′′ ), 127.8 (C-9 ′′′ ), which verify that 6 and 4 share the same fatty acid side chain. The geometry configuration of the double bonds in the side chain was deduced as 6? Z , 9? Z , based on the typical 13 C NMR data of an upfield shift allylic methylene at δ C 25.2 (C-8 ′′′ ), and two bisallylic methylenes at δ C 26.6 (C- 5 ′′′ ) and δ C 26.6 (C-11 ′′′ ) ( Gunstone et al., 1977 ; Song et al., 2021 ). Moreover, the sugar unit NMR data in the literature ( Usui et al., 2017 ; Bock and Pedersen, 1983 ), and the coupling constant value J ′′ 1 -2’’ = 8.8 Hz enabled us to determine the relative configuration of the sugar moiety as β -glucose. The D-configuration at the anomeric center of glucose was established by acid hydrolysis and GC analysis. Compound 6 was elucidated as Belamcandnoate F.

caption.paragraph: Fig. 2. The key HMBC correlations () for compounds 1–6.

subSection.paragraph: In an i n vitro bioassay, the cytotoxicities (against HCT-116, HepG2, BGC-823, A549, and MCF-7 five human cancer cell lines with paclitaxel as a positive control), antiinflammation (inhibitory effects against lipopolysaccharide-induced nitric oxide (NO) production on BV2 microglial cells), and antioxidation (Fe2+ /cysteine-induced liver microsomal lipid peroxidation) of the isolated compounds were evaluated. The cytotoxic activities showed that compound 2 exhibited moderate cytotoxic activities against the HCT-116, HepG2, and BGC823 cell lines with IC 50 values of 6.80, 5.74, and 5.95 μ M ( Table 3 ). Compound 4 displayed moderated cytotoxic activities against the HCT-116, HepG2, and BGC823 cell lines with IC 50 values of 5.73, 6.86, and 1.69 μ M. Compounds 2 and 5 exhibited 72.27 and 58.98% inhibitory activities, respectively, against the Fe 2+ /cysteine-induced liver microsomal lipid peroxidation at a concentration of 10 μ M (curcumin as the positive control drug, 87.08%). The anti-inflammatory results displayed that they were inactive with IC 50 values > 10 μ M.

In addition, the brief structure and activity were discussed. Compounds 2 and 4 with the 5 ′ -OCH 3 group displayed significant cytotoxic activities, which suggested that the presence of 5 ′ -OCH 3 might be crucial for the cytotoxic activities. Moreover, OCH 3 at C-5 ′ in the saturated long-chain fatty acid acylated derivatives of isoflavones might play an important role in antioxidant activities. However, there were too little data to conclude whether the length and the degree of unsaturation of the fatty acid side chain are equally important. More evidence should be supported in the future.

I. domestica
, a type of traditional Chinese medicine rich in isoflavones, is mainly used to treat sore throat. The diverse structures and inspired bioactivities of isoflavones from
I. domestica
make wider application prospects. In our research, six undescribed long-chain fatty acid acylated derivatives with very long chain unsaturated and saturated fatty acids (C14–C18) were obtained. This is the first report of long-chain fatty acid (C14–C18) ester derivatives of isoflavones from natural products. Our findings enrich the chemical and biological diversity of flavonoid glycosides, and provide a new research idea for compound modification.

A JASCO P-2000 automatic digital polarimeter was used to record optical rotations. UV spectra were conducted on a JASCO V-650 spectrophotometer. A Nicolet 5700 spectrometer using an FT-IR microscope transmission method was used to obtain IR spectra. Bruker-600 spectrometer was employed to measure NMR spectra. HRESIMS data were measured on Dionex UltiMate 3000 UHPLC and Thermo Scientific Q Exactive Focus Mass Spectrometer. Analytical HPLC was performed on an Agilent 1260 infinity system equipped with a DAD-UV detector. Preparative HPLC was conducted on a CXTH system (Beijing Chuangxintongheng instrument Co. Ltd., People’ s Republic of China ), equipped with a UV3000 detector using a YMC-Pack ODS-A column (250 × 20 mm , 5 μm, Kyoto , Japan ). ODS (50 μ m, YMC, Japan ), and silica gel (200–300 mesh, Qingdao Marine Chemical Factory, Qingdao, People’ s Republic of China ) were used for column chromatography. Silica gel GF 254 plates purchased from Qingdao Marine Chemical Factory (Qingdao, People’ s Republic of China ) were used for TLC analysis.

caption.paragraph: 1 H (600 MHz) and 13 C (150 MHz) NMR data of compounds 4–6 (DMSO‑ d ).

subSection.paragraph:
Rhizomes of
Iris domestica
L. ( Iridaceae ) [the name
Belamcanda chinensis
(L.) DC ( Iridaceae ) was recorded in Chinense Pharmacopoeia for 2020] were purchased from Anguo ( Hebei Province , P.R. China ) in September (autumn) 2017, and identified by Prof. Lin Ma ( Institute of Materia Medica ). A voucher specimen (S-2895) was deposited at Institute of Materia Medica , Chinese Academy of Medical Sciences and Peking Union Medical College
.

The air-dried and powdered rhizomes of
I. domestica
( 50 kg ) were extracted with 95% ethanol (3 × 2 h × 120 L) to give 7.8 kg residues after evaporation under reduced pressure. The residue was successively partitioned with dichloromethane ( CH 2 Cl 2 ), ethyl acetate (EtOAc), and n -butanol ( n -BuOH). Iridal-type triterpenoids were mainly distributed in dichloromethane extract based on the TLC analysis. Subsequently, the CH 2 Cl 2 extract was chromatographed on a silica gel column and eluted with petroleum/acetone (10:1, 5:1, 3:1, 2:1, 1:1, v/v) to obtain five fractions A-E. Fraction C was subjected to an ODS column and eluted with a gradient of MeOH–H 2 O of 65–100% to obtain eight fractions C-a to C-h. Fraction C-g was run on a silica gel column eluting with petroleum ether-ethyl acetate (20:1, 10:1, 5:1, 3:1, 2:1, 1:1, 1:2) to obtain seven subfractions C-g-1 to C-g-7. C-g-3 was separated by preparative HPLC (MeCN–H 2 O 75:25, 4 mL/min) to afford six subfractions: C-g-3-1 to C-g-3-6. C-g-3-3 was also fractioned by preparative HPLC (MeOH–H 2 O 85:15, 4 mL/min) to obtain compounds 1 ( 4.2 mg ), 2 ( 6.8 mg ), and 6 (3.0 mg). Fraction C-g-3-4 was purified by preparative HPLC (MeOH–H 2 O 84:16, 4 mL/min) to afford compounds 3 ( 1.9 mg ), 4 ( 11.8 mg ), and 5 (10.0 mg).

Pale yellow oil, [ α ] D 20 –82 ( c 0.1, MeOH); UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 267 (3.26), 342 (0.82) nm; IR u max 3224, 2925, 2861, 1736, 1635, 1452, 1075 cm 1 ; 1 H NMR and 13 C NMR data see Table 1 ; HRESIMS m/z 703.33234 [M + H] + (calcd C 37 H 51 O 13 , 703.33242).

Compound 4 ( 2.4 mg ) was dissolved in CH 3 OH (3 mL), and excess NaOH aqueous solution (1 mol/L, 5 mL) was added. The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 24 h. The solution was acidified to a pH of 4 using 1 mol/L HCl and extracted with CH 2 Cl 2 . The CH 2 Cl 2 extract was analyzed by MS and two molecular formulas were probed: C 24 H 26 O 13 (M = 522) and C 18 H 32 O 2 (M = 280), which indicated that the chain length of fatty acid of 4 was C-18. Utilizing the same methods, alkaline hydrolysis products of compounds 1–3 , and 5–6 were detected by MS to determine that the carbon chain length of fatty acids were 14, 14, 16, 18 and 18, respectively. The structural elucidation of the glucoside moiety of 4 demonstrated that it shared the same structure with the known compound iridin. Iridin was obtained from the reaction mixture via preparative HPLC (MeCN–H 2 O 30:70, 4 mL/min) ( Bugoni et al., 2015 ).

heading.emphasis: 4.5. Acidic hydrolysis of iridin, iristectorin A, tectoridin

subSection.paragraph: Iridin ( 1 mg ), iristectorin A ( 1.5 mg ), and tectoridin ( 1.2 mg ) were hydrolyzed with HCl (2 mol/L, 3 mL) and reacted at 90 ◦ C for 2 h, respectively. The reaction mixture was partitioned with CH 2 Cl 2 three times (5 mL × 3). After evaporating under reduced pressure, the CH 2 Cl 2 extract was analyzed by MS to find the aglycone (C 18 H 16 O 8 , M = 360). The aqueous phase extract was placed in a desiccator overnight. Then, Lcysteine methyl ester hydrochloride ( 5 mg ) and anhydrous pyridine (1 mL) were added to the aqueous layer. The mixture was vigorously stirred at 60 ◦ C for 2 h. Then, 200 μ L trimethylsilylimidazole was added to the mixture and kept at 60 ◦ C for 2 h. The solution was poured into water (3 mL), followed by extraction with hexane (3 × 5 mL). The authentic sugar (D- and L-glucoses) derivatives were obtained using the same methods. The hexane mixture (5 μ L) was analyzed by GC chromatography and subjected to an Agilent 7890A gas chromatograph with an HP-5 column ( 60 m × 0.25 mm , with a 0.25 μ m film, Dikma) and an FID detector under the following conditions: column temperature: 200–280 ◦ C; programmed increase: 10 ◦ C/min; carrier gas: N 2 (1 mL/ min); injector and detector temperature: 280 ◦ C; injection volume: 5 μ L; split ratio: 1/50. The configuration of the sugar moiety was determined by comparing the retention time with the derivatives of authentic samples. The retention times of D and L-glucose were 29.405 and 30.219 min, respectively, which helped identify the configuration of the sugar moiety of compounds 1–6 as D-glucose ( Han et al., 2019 ; Liu et al., 2009 ).

Cytotoxic activities of compounds 1–6 against HCT-116, HepG2, BGC-823, A549 and MCF-7 cells were measured by using the MTT method. Briefly, test cells in culture medium 100 μ L were seeded in each well of 96-well plates (Falcon, CA). Cells were treated in triplicate with 10 μ L of grade concentrations 0.1, 1, 10 μ M of the compounds at 37 ◦ C. After 72 h, a 20 μ L aliquot of MTT solution ( 5 mg /mL) was added to the wells. The cultures were incubated for another 4 h, and then 100 μ L of “triplex solution” (10% SDS/5% isobutanol/10 mM HCl) was added. The plates were incubated at 37 ◦ C in 5% CO 2 overnight. The OD values were measured at 570 nm by a plate reader (VERSA Max, Molecular Devices, Sunnyvale, CA). Average values determined from triplicate readings

were used for the inhibitory rate calculation by the formula: ( ODcontrol well – ODtreated well )/ ODcontrol well – ODblank well × 100%. The IC 50 was calculated using Logistic regression from three independent tests. Paclitaxel was used as the positive control with IC 50 values of 0.2, 10.69, 2.08, 2.68, 19 n M, respectively ( Li et al., 2019a ,b).

Compounds 1–6 were tested for their inhibitory effect on LPSinduced NO production in the BV2 cell line. The BV2 cells were plated in a 96-well plate and pretreated with the compounds for 24 h followed by an additional 24 h of LPS (0.3 μg/mL) exposure. The Griess reaction was used to determine the nitrite content in the culture supernatant. NaNO 2 served as a standard to assess the NO 2 concentration. The OD values were recorded at 550 nm . Curcumin was used as the positive control. Cell viability was measured by an MTT assay ( Li et al., 2019a ,b).

The antioxidant activities of compounds 1–6 were determined by an MDA colorimetric assay in Fe 2+ /cysteine-induced liver microsomal lipid peroxidation. Hepatic microsomes were maintained in 0.1 M PBS (pH 7.4), and the system contained 1.5 mg /mL liver microsomal protein, 0.1 μ M compounds and 200 μ M cysteine and was cultured in a 37 ◦ C water bath for 15 min FeSO 4 (50 μ M) was added into the reactions, and the plates were cultured in a 37 ◦ C water bath for an additional 15 min. The reactions were terminated by the addition of 20% TCA. The reaction mixtures were centrifuged at 2000 r/min for 10 min, and then 1 mL of each supernatant was combined with 1 mL of 0.67% TBA and cultured in a boiling water bath for 10 min. The optical density (OD) of each reaction solution was measured with a microplate reader at 532 nm . The content of MDA was used as a measure of oxidizing strength: lower MDA contents indicated stronger oxidation resistance. The concentration of MDA was obtained using the following formula: C ( n M) = [(OD– 0.006)/ 0.07] × 10, and the antioxidant activities of the compounds were calculated using the following formula: Inhibition (%) = 1–[C(sample)– C(blank))/(C(model)–C(blank))] × 100 ( Chen et al., 2013 ; Liu et al., 2019 ).
The authors declare no competing financial interests.
The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.

2016-I2
M-1–010)
